content.div:
When you've done more Bop magazine and Tiger Beat features than your average Montreal rock musician, it's time to face facts: You've got a tweenage audience. That's been the case for pop-punks Simple Plan since their first album, 2002's No Pads, No Helmets . . . Just Balls, charted four hits and went double-platinum in the States.

Nearly 10 years later, and with their fourth album (Get Your Heart On, due out Tuesday), drummer Chuck Comeau knows the kids still dig them.

"Obviously, the common knowledge is that it's all, like, young girls, you know, from 12 to 16. And I'm not going to deny that there's a lot of young fans. It's amazing," he says. (The new album cover, a shot of a teenybopper bedroom plastered in spoofy Simple Plan pin-ups, even mines the phenomenon for a few laughs.)

But Comeau knows there are SP fans who are no longer kids, who've grown up with the band, and "are still front-row and still rocking out." And then you've got what Comeau calls "surprising fans."

"We just played Germany, and we were playing alongside, like, Slipknot and these super-heavy bands. We were, like, 'OK, we're going to get absolutely killed on the stage. They're going to throw rocks at us.' And then you go on, and they're loving it.

"It's funny, it's so hard to pin down one type of fan," says the drummer. But since forming the band in the late '90s with old friends Pierre Bouvier (lead vocals), Sebastien Lefebvre (rhythm guitar), David Desrosiers (bass) and Jeff Stinco (guitar), Comeau says he began to acknowledge one simple element that brought their fan base together - something that went a little deeper than a mutual appreciation of bratty pop-punk hooks.

"A lot of the time, what people on the outside don't get is that, on every album, we have these deeper, more emotional songs," says Comeau, name-checking tracks, including 2004's ode to teen angst, Welcome to My Life and 2008's single, Save You (a song frontman Bouvier reportedly wrote about his brother's battle with cancer).

"We've been hearing since we started, whether it's through letters or meeting fans at concerts, stories about how our songs have been important to (fans), or it helped them go through tough times," says Comeau. "When you're young, you kind of listen to that and think, 'OK, that's cool.' But maybe you don't completely believe it, or whatever.

"As you start to hear this from people from Brazil, from people from Australia, from Czech Republic and Russia and France, you start to think, 'Maybe this is really real, and our music really has an impact.'"

Comeau says the band kept those fans in mind while making the new record - a fact that transcended mere inspiration while they were writing the album-closing track, This Song Saved My Life, a year ago. Crowd-sourcing, it turns out, can be an effective method of writing rock lyrics.

Comeau says he wanted to write a song about how music - "not just our music" - can affect a person's life. "We were in the studio and we were trying to come up with lyrics and we were like, 'You know what? If we want it to feel real, we have to ask the fans directly.'"

They turned to Twitter (the band has more than 131,000 followers), asked how the band's music made their fans feel, and waited for the response. "We started getting literally thousands of tweets," says Comeau, messages that the band pored through, searching for lines "that resonated most with us" so they could write a melody. When it was done, they invited fans to join them in studio to record some choral vocals. Twenty-five people from Germany, Japan, Chicago and Montreal arrived at a recording studio in Vancouver. "At first, we were a little worried. I mean, I hope they can sing," Comeau jokes. "But they completely nailed it," he says of their part. "Gives me shivers."

Get Your Heart On, recorded between Vancouver and Montreal with producer Brian Howe (Hedley, Daughtry), sounds as though it was made with the fans in mind - albeit in a different sense than the story of This Song Saved My Life's creation.

While their last record, 2008's Simple Plan, found the band veering closer to pop than punk (notably, they teamed with Top 40 hitmakers, including Max Martin and Danjahandz), Get Your Heart On embraces an uptempo, traditional guitar-rock sound more in keeping with the band's earlier days.

"I think this one, for us, was all about going back to our roots, and the experience of the first and second record," says Comeau, explaining that, after a few years of touring the last record - which featured material with a "darker, more introspective" tack - the band craved playing something "faster and more like a party."

"You know, a lot of times kids will say, 'I like the sound of the first record or the second record' I want a song like that,'" says Comeau.

But that's not why Get Your Heart On feels a bit like a throwback. The band loves their fans, but crowd-sourcing has its limits. "You have to write for yourself," he says, "something that is honest and that you're stoked about, and hope that they'll like it, as well."

Get Your Heart On is out June 21.

entry.title: Best and Worst MMVA Moments

link.Abstract: Check out the highs and lows from the 2011 MuchMusic Video Awards.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract:
Biggest Surprise Shut-Out:
Everyone assumed the UR Fave International Artist award would go to Britney Spears, since she was leading the way for weeks on MuchMusic's online poll. But the fan-voted award ended up going to Lady Gaga, which didn't sit well with Spears fans, who made #MMVAfail a trending hashtag on Twitter Sunday night.
link.title: Gaga
